newsitem.title: HONG KONG: PRESS DIGEST-Hong Kong Newspaper Headlines-Feb 10.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST-Hong Kong Newspaper Headlines-Feb 10.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Hong Kong press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- WEN WEI PO -- People in Beijing looked forward to the return of Hong Kong to China while celebrating the Spring Festival.
-- Some World Trade Organisation officials said they were hopeful China and Taiwan could both join the WTO this year.

-- EXPRESS NEWS -- Because more mainland Chinese were using forged passports to go overseas via Hong Kong, the Immigration Department would install new equipment to detect false documents. Last year, 2,192 false travel documents were seized, up 20 percent from the year before.

-- SING TAO DAILY -- A senior Chinese rocket designer said that when China launched two American satellites in 1992, its American partner had refused to reveal some important technical information for political reasons, which was responsible for the failures. He said the booming market economy had also brought down the quality of rocket production in the country.

-- MING PAO -- The Shenzhen government has decided to close more than 20 private schools this month, leaving more than 7,000 students out of school. The schools had been criticised for poor conditions and accepting children of non-Shenzhen residents.

-- HONGKONG STANDARD -- Beijing's Central Leading Group on Hong Kong and Macau Affairs, the ruling party's highest decision-making body on the handover, has decided to accord Hong Kong Chief Executive-designate Tung Chee-hwa the status of a state leader.

-- A shabby Guangzhou clinic was doing a roaring trade in what it called giving women back their virginity. The doctors who specialised in hymen restoration said that Hong Kong women were flocking to its doors.

-- SOUTH CHINA MORNING POST -- Hong Kong handbag exporters who faced punishing anti-dumping tariffs for shipments into Europe had been given a glimmer of hope that they could see the duties drastically reduced.
